reply_text:
misscrystal:
I have a lovely tiny sidewalk cafe nearby I miss too.
I have a favorite small pizza place and I legitimately cried about it closing at my therapy session yesterday. Well, I think it was more about this feeling of the normalcy of life slowly slipping away, but yeah. I miss it and I’m worried that being such a small place, they won’t survive the economical repercussions.
Onto the fun stuff: the subway was closed, now if you can’t work from home, you have to use buses or cars. There can’t be more than 10 people on a bus at any given time. Which is a genius plan except I live in a city of 5+ million people with a huge river in the middle and very few bridges across. Angry mobs are storming buses, no one can really enforce the 10 people rule.
Our mayor is Vitaly Klitschko, a former world boxing champion, and I’m a bit horrified of his future brilliant initiatives.

reply_text:
I’m in the US near a major city and everyone has been instructed to work from home if possible. As Fiverr Freelancers, we’re all accustomed to working from home and have systems set up for us to do so. Our spouses, partners, roommates etc… not so much!
My wife and I had to set up a whole separate private space for her and she’s going through that process we’ve all been through with learning how to work from home (she’s a therapist seeing client’s via tele-health). It’s almost like having co-workers again except we can’t go out for coffee or lunch and there no going home and complaining about how your co-worker is annoying you… lol!
Stay safe everyone!

reply_text:
Some people think “that won’t happen to me” and somehow feel it’s only for other people.
There is no way to avoid coming into contact with it for everyone in the world at some point in time. What we are trying to do is
“flatten the curve” so everyone does not get it all at once.
Some get it now and some can get it later on so hospitals and society won’t be so overwhelmed.
nytimes.com 1
Which Country Has Flattened the Curve for the Coronavirus? 1
These charts show the trajectory of the coronavirus pandemic in each country. New cases have dwindled in China and South Korea, but the virus continues to spread rapidly in most of the world.
Some may never get it if that initial spike in new cases can be brought down soon.

Keep healthy as much as possible y’all!

reply_text:
Hello from Florida
What an interesting time we are in as a global economy. In my neck of the woods on the east coast beaches are closed, stores readily running out of supplies, business are shutting down everyday, police are breaking up beach parties, others getting on social media telling their friends to dine out.
Not much of a spread yet but a well know aerospace facility in my town just got a case of covid-19 and havent shut down. That facility employees hundreds of engineers. I live next door to an Airbnb for outatowners only. I don’t understand why people are traveling out of state/country right now. I’m afraid many are not taking this virus seriously.
In terms of Fiverr, it’s slowed down a bit but steady. I’m thankful we have the opportunity to work safely from home. THANK YOU Micha and the Fiverr team for building this place for us!! I ended up here during the last recession so I know we are likely in for some hard times ahead but together we can overcome this!

Doing okay here in the UK. My partner is a paramedic so we’re isolating to avoid spreading to vulnerable people and flatten the curve. As of right now the UK is not routinely testing healthcare workers for COVID-19 although I have seen a petition going around to make it happen. It’s an impossible situation to be in. We need our frontline workers to be healthy and available to work during this crisis. We need them, but how do we know they aren’t spreading it further without testing?
Just trying to stay positive and hope for the best. I hope you’re all staying safe :).

reply_text:
I am in Maryland. East coast of the US. We have one death in the county I live in and over 100 cases state wide. Everything is shut down! Grocery stores are having a hard time keeping stock of disinfecting wipes and general cleaning supplies. They have Senior hours for people over 60 from 7-8am at the stores.
I am a Teacher by day, so off and trying to enjoy the time. No clue when and if we go back to work. Right now it is set for the end of the month to go back, but hard to see how with cases growing.
The biggest issue as I am sure the news has said is testing. It is so limited right now. To get tested requires so much effort, and as it becomes more available, I am sure the numbers will spike significantly.
Watching how different states handle this vs how the Govt is responding is interesting.
I do not want to go into that. I feel horrible for anyone affected by this. Seeing images. from Italy is scary, and I sure hope the US learns from China and Europes lessons and listens.
Only time will tell, and not having a known outcome for this is anxiety producing.

all clients are terrified.
No, I can assure you, they are not. Just because you feel that way (and I’m sad to hear that this is your experience), does not mean all Fiverr buyers are quaking in their boots. Please don’t make general sweeping statements, unless you have facts to prove your claims.

reply_text:
mjensen415:
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
I would like the community to come together and arrange for me and my dog and possibly my girlfriend to be airlifted immediately to Pitcairn Island.
Thank you for the kind offer.
More seriously, I’d really like Fiverr to maybe go with @eoinfinnegan’s earlier suggestion of Fiverr relaxing St. Levels and maybe putting some UI tweaks in place to make sellers’ lives easier.
I’ve been bombed bya client repeatedly ordering in bulk from my single article gig with 1-day delivery, despite me asking him numerous times to message me before placing bulk orders. I’ve finally lost it and just canceled his last order. However, my stats will likely be ruined soon anyway.
The thing is, this wouldn’t happen if we had a feature to limit how many of a certain gig package a single buyer can buy at a time.
Another thing that would make life easier is a 24-hour or 48-hour auto-accept feature for disputes. I got bombed yesterday with lots of people who aren’t replying to extension requests, likely because it is the weekend and they are doing what normies do and are taking time out until Monday.
And would it really be so hard to darken and increase the font size of the fonts in messages, order requirements, and custom offers? - Or let sellers customize this?

reply_text:
Hi everyone! I come from Italy. As you may have already heard, here the situation is truly tragic, especially in Northern Italy. We’ve been in quarantine for 13 days, all non-essential services are closed, and the military and police officers monitor the cities. Many have lost their jobs and self-employed workers are the ones who are suffering a severe blow, economically speaking. Fortunately, I am doing fine. The company I work for allows smart-working and when I don’t work, I have online lessons and dedicate myself to freelancing ( well, and Netflix too). I’ve noticed that several other companies are demanding for people to work remotely. I imagine that in this tragic scenario the world of work gets adapted to the circumstances and I think this is positive for those who now find it difficult to raise some money.
Either way, I hope you are all fine. Wherever you come from, try to stay safe!

thread_name: How are YOU doing?
thread_text:
Hi everyone. If you’re like me, you’ve been getting these “What are we doing” emails from companies about COVID-19. And… that’s great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!

one of daughters friends has it. To say its bad is an understatement and this is (a formerly) healthy 20 something. Now its a waiting game to see if anyone here has it. reply_text:
lenasemenkova:
This is getting ridiculous if I’m honest.
On my island, we have had no cases but 1 that was sent to the mainland. The only way to get here is by ferry. All businesses are closed and already people are losing their jobs and can’t pay their bills. It would be easy to prohibit passengers on the ferry and just use the service for goods. This way, life here could continue as something like normal and small businesses would at least stand a chance.
Instead, tourists can get a 10,000 euro fine for not answering the door when a policeman calls to see if they are obeying by quarantine rules. (This means they press buzzers on apartment main entrances that usually don’t work, and guess what time they call?) Businesses can also get a 3,000 fine for opening and at least one has already been fined for trying to do something productive and having staff on-site doing paintwork and maintenance.
It is all madness.
And if you thought Coronavirus was bad, wait for rat flu!
Mail Online – 24 Mar 20
Man who died on bus in China tests positive for virus RATS spread
The victim died on a vehicle in Shandong as he made his way to work and was found to be suffering from hantavirus, which infected rats spread through bites, droppings, urine and saliva.
Then you have that minor problem that is when economies nosedive, public health goes through the floor. Infant mortality rates go up, life expectancy shortens, violent crime goes up, the rate of people choosing to end it all skyrockets, rates of malnutrition go up, disease spreads more easily as a result, homelessness rates skyrocket…
This isn’t just getting ridiculous, it’s dangerous, and the aftermath of this is going to be catastrophic. .

thread_name: How are YOU doing?
thread_text:
Hi everyone. If you’re like me, you’ve been getting these “What are we doing” emails from companies about COVID-19. And… that’s great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.

reply_text:
I wonder what life will be like a year from now, or two years from now. We have no real leadership here. (edit: I’m referring to our country, not fiverr.) Nothing is being done at all aside from a handful of scientists in various places studying this. It’s crazy people can’t get tested. We can’t do tele-doctor visits. Not enough masks available for healthcare workers who have to wear two masks, two sets of gloves which they remove the top layer for each patient, etc.
I can’t imagine what our pitiful little local emergency waiting room must be like, parents with screaming babies waiting for hours, homeless people, all sick and coughing, overworked understaffed nurses. Hope I don’t have to find out, in person.
A small ray of hope:
They found the virus doesn’t like hot humid weather, over 63 degrees f. It slows it down.
They also found it does not mutate due to the way it’s put together, unlike the flu, so any vaccine will likely be permanent.
Best hope: a year from now a good vaccine will be available to anyone. And the drug that shows so much promise is widely available to anyone who needs it.
Try your hardest to keep from getting it in the meantime. Do whatever it takes.

reply_text: Our Ministry of Health commissioned a bunch of ads and infographics explaining to people how not to get the virus in a fun visual way. One of the tips was to avoid wild animals at all costs. But “wild” got lost in translation because the translator was bad at their job. The designer was even more of a genius because they illustrated this tip with a golden retriever instead of a boar or a bat. That triggered a wave of panicked citizens bringing their dogs to the shelters, throwing them out to the streets and occasionally putting them down. Be good at your job, people. Wash your hands and think of the puppies.

thread_name: How are YOU doing?

reply_text:
In a week’s time, there has been more than 330 people diagnosed with COVID-19 and 3 Arkansas residents have died from the disease. We have yet to see a huge number of cases here but, according to our mayor, he doesn’t trust the numbers. He feels the number is much more than four in our county. We’ve been told that the hospitals have the test but don’t want to use them unless they absolutely have no choice.
In fact, from what I’m hearing, the hospitals are turning people away and not testing those even with outward symptoms of this disease. They just tell them to quarantine themselves and wait for 14 days unless they get worse.
I’m trying to avoid the crowds as much as possible. It was 80+ degrees here today, and I would have walked our local park, but got the word that large groups of people were in the park with their kids. No thank you!
Stay well everyone!

There was a two pack limit the last I checked and when people tried to walk out the store with more than that, security removed the extras from their buggie. Most everything is manageable here but it’s allergy season and we practically live in a pollen bowl (surrounded by trees and flowers giving off pollen).
Continuing with odd jobs and writing on my end. A group of some artists on a platform I participate on have thrown together some challenges to keep the community occupied for a while so I got that going. About to fix some tea as I’ve reached my coffee limit for the day. Stay safe out there.

Everybody has stocked up on food so the supermarkets have been under pressure.

Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text: Our Bangladeshi people are in a very dangerous state, the corona virus has seized us, the government is not collecting kits for testing, many people in Bangladesh will die if they continue this way, may Allah protect us all.

Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text: Lockdown in whole India!

thread_name: How are YOU doing?
thread_text:
Hi everyone. If you’re like me, you’ve been getting these “What are we doing” emails from companies about COVID-19. And… that’s great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text: I hope all will be ok soon!!

mjensen415:
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
I’m from India. We’re still in lockdown situation here (till April 14).
Although, new positive cases are increasing some good news are getting reported too!
A 93-year-old man and his wife (age 88) has survived the virus and discharged from hospital in Kerala. He’s the oldest person in India to survive COVID-19. Also, the largest lockdown in the world has impacted in the sudden remarkable decrease in pollution!

reply_text:
Hi Everyone,
I’m from India and LIFE IS HARD. For some people being at home is a good thing because they can take a break from that daily hectic life, but for some people, like me, it hard as both my mom and dad are ill and as the only son I have to find a way to make some money. Hence I’m here on Fiverr trying to make some sales. And as a new seller on Fiverr, we all know how hard it is.
Well, I hope everyone is doing well and safe at home. And hope that all this will be over soon.
Stay safe guy!!

reply_text:
So I work with theaters a lot (now it’s obviously slowing down due to the virus because no one can have shows). But I got an order from one of them today. I asked if they were sure they wanted to proceed given the situation because wouldn’t want to charge people for something that will get cancelled 100%.
They said: “All the shows are being hosted online-everyone does their part via webcam from their homes, everything has changed and we are making it work!”
And it just made me happy to see how people change their process and adapt to the hardships. If there is a silver lining in all of this, it’s how creative and inspiring the human spirit really is.

Hi everyone. If you’re like me, you’ve been getting these “What are we doing” emails from companies about COVID-19. And… that’s great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
I am Shkelzeni From Kosovo , so far we have only 140 infected with covid-19, the National Institute of Public Health of Kosovo so far has taken strict measures where they are proving positive.
Hang on, people! Everything will be normal soon

Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).

reply_text:
We all need to adapt to not leaving our homes, probably for a very long time. I can’t see this getting better until a vaccine is developed and widely distributed to everyone, which will be at least a year from now.
I hope everyone here is prepared to stay inside that long. Going any place where there are people puts us at risk. The more people now who are not going out, the sooner our health care systems can find ways to deal with all the patients they have, and the fewer of us will get the virus.
I have food delivered to my home. I only touch the bags with rubber gloves on and I wash all of it. I leave the bags of canned foods without touching them for three days. It can take that long for the virus to die when it’s on bags or other surfaces.
There may come a time when I can no longer get food delivered and I’m sure most people here still need to go out to get food. Please wear a mask or cloth over your nose and mouth when you go out.
We are actually experiencing nature adjusting and balancing out our population to protect the earth, the air and lower pollution.

I caught my dad in a store yesterday (my parents live nearby). He takes all the necessary precautions but he’s 82 and we agreed that I’ll be buying whatever groceries they need and leave them on their doorstep.
He loves fresh bread with his coffee in the morning and who knows how long he’s been sneaking out. Mom says it gives him purpose and we shouldn’t get in the way of him hunting baguettes. I’m horrified and amused at the same time.

reply_text:
I’m in one of the most affected states in the USA (NJ) where we have nearly 50,000 cases already. We’re simply not leaving the house at all. Grocery delivery has shut down everywhere around here, and stores aren’t offering pickup services either. We have people in delicate health in the household. So, we’re living on canned and boxed foods that go through a rigorous self-quarantine and decontamination of their own once they hit our porch. It’s crazy, and maybe excessive, but taking no chances.
Hope everyone’s being safe and staying sane out there. A good time to take up some stress relief habits and watch comedies or read light-hearted books.

Sorry to hear of all that! What a nightmare.
We have no working plumbing currently in our ancient house and I’m afraid to let in anyone to fix it since our area is a very high covid area and I don’t want to be around any strangers.
Yesterday we had a complete blackout for a while. Between no plumbing and no lights or electricity it was surreal. At least in a cave we could build a fire and use the outside “restroom”.
I found myself yelling out the front door to the neighbors to find out what was happening with the electricity. We aren’t supposed to go outside at all here. I felt like a trapped animal.
Lena I hope that they are at least working at putting out that fire! You sound like you are in a bad situation there.

thread_name: How are YOU doing?
thread_text:
Hi everyone. If you’re like me, you’ve been getting these “What are we doing” emails from companies about COVID-19. And… that’s great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
Many states here in the U.S. are slowly opening their economies - my state included. To say I’m nervous about how this will all play out is an understatement. As much as I want to get back into the gym or lift weights in the local park, another part of me is saying, this is going to get worse before it gets better.
Last night, instead of attending a concert in Memphis to see Motionless in White, I was at home. The concert was postponed (understandable) and who knows if the concert will even happen. The bright spot of the whole thing is that my school will remain shut down for the rest of the academic year. Now, I do need to go in once a week to get things done such as auditing for next year and payments.
As it stands now, my job is being terminated due to restructuring. I was actually called to ask if I wanted another position in the school as a parapro. While it’s not what I want all the way around, I know I can do the job and will do it as I do anything else in my life. I await the final decision from the board to see if they will make the approval. So, we’ll see!
Thankfully, the Fiverr work has increased, which may be due in part to finding my best gig on page one again with the culmination of an ad I ran.
In the grand scheme of things, I’m just playing the wait and see game and doing work when it comes in.
Stay safe and healthy Fiverr friends!

reply_text:
QUARANTINE RESULTS REPORT
Since I do reports all the time at work I find it natural to make a report on what I did during quarantine since this is the last Q-day in my country (Croatia). Starting tomorrow business should be slowly returning to normal.
So:
I published 2 new books
I wrote 3 new books and prepared drafts for 12 more
I wrote 5 e-books for students struggling to learn online since schools are closed
I started Fiverr seller account and earned 92 USD
I designed furniture for my backyard and build it together with my crafty neighbor
I repurposed frame of the old trampoline into the gym area
I planted some flowers for the first time in my life
I draw a big “NO SMOKING” sign in my backyard
I started a YouTube channel and helped a kid who was being harassed by others on the live stream
And
I cleaned and organized my office (this lasted for one day and now it is back to random mess)
I discovered there is nothing wrong with my car battery, for some reason car wants to start only if the shift gear is in a certain position
I gain 10 pounds (and then I decided to make gym outside :D)
I actually planted seeds of watermelon next to flowers.
END OF REPORT
Marina no smoking
1600×1200 231 KB

Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
Same here…
I am also learning to play the piano… I am self learning since last week…

thread_text:
Hi everyone. If you’re like me, you’ve been getting these “What are we doing” emails from companies about COVID-19. And… that’s great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 45” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 37”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
It’s gonna take a week or so for the symptoms to pop-up for the people out in the streets and after that, we’re probably looking at mass lockdowns around the world again.
cyaxrex:
On the upside, though. all them, protesters are getting lots of vitamin D.
Nope, most major protests start after the sun goes down.

ldnarquitectura:
My older sister, who lives in France, is in a hospital there since several weeks
I’m sorry for your sisters situation. However, she might be lucky if France is still treating oncology patients. In Malta and lots of other countries, most cancer screening and treatment is pretty much on hold at the moment. I have a friend with lung cancer who hasn’t been to the hospital in weeks.
ldnarquitectura:
COVID19 is not so dangerous as cancer.
More people have died in building accidents on Malta this year than they have of COVID. However, the constriction industry is the only industry that has been allowed to continue operating as normal throughout the pandemic. Apparently, the cost to the economy would be to great if they ceased operations.
Then you have the suicide rate in the U.S. In some states, they have already recorded more suicides this year than during the entirety on 2019. Sadly, most people aren’t interested in looking at the bigger picture.
I hope your sister recovers and that you can get to see her soon.

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr

Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: worthy statement in current scenario, May God protect us all

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: Great post for the current crisis …respect and thnks

reply_text:
Now if only Fiverr could devote that much energy into removing the problems that penalize sellers for what buyers do wrong! Perhaps not as strong a public relations opportunity.
Sorry, but these things frustrate me. We’re supposed to oooh and aahhh about this gesture, but it’s a deflection of the systemic issues within the platform.
I’m not saying Fiverr owes us anything because of Corona – not at all. I’m just saying that if they’re going to essentially brag about the good they’re doing for sellers, they should also address the unfairness that they’ve attached to the selling experience here – stuff we’ve been venting about here and elsewhere for literally years but nothing changes.
After all, the unjust elements of Fiverr affect sellers’ income from the platform the most and no amount of free resources is going to change that.

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: Nice information. Its helps us

reply_text:
Hi Matt @mjensen415,
Actually, there is something Fiverr could do to help its seller freelancer community in a direct and probably not too complicated way (a bit of coding and sending out automated emails, I think).
As it’s possible that some of us may have to apply for government funds or a mortgage respite, prove to their health insurance that they don’t earn much or at all due to this pandemic to not have to keep paying their monthly dues based on last year’s earnings/tax declaration, etc.,
a “paper” (email) from Fiverr stating the seller’s revenue for any given month could be more helpful and get less suspicious looks than that csv file one can download. Staff in such organisations often don’t know much if anything about freelancing or at least platforms like Fiverr/the gig economy, too, and often ask for “something official”.
Something that looks credible and official, with Fiverr’s address and such, that states something like:
XY is registered on our platform as a freelancer and earned $$$ revenue in (February 2020).
I’m sure Fiverr has people who can make sure that that “revenue statement” will be fine from a legal standpoint for Fiverr.
This has been already suggested before COVID-19, as something like that, especially as a yearly statement, would be really useful for tax and other purposes, but I think in the face of the current situation, it might just have become even more relevant.
I hope this can be considered/passed on to the relevant people. Thanks!

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text:
Thank you for these precious informations!
Take care of yourselves everyone

As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: It’s is a great idea

More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.

In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We’ve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr

Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online – how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government’s guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: Thanks for creating the post. Stay home stay safe.

thread_name: Anybody else in self-isolation?
thread_text:
I’m currently the only person I know in my family or friends group that has covid-19 symptoms. UK testing is pretty much non-existent unless you’re in hospital, but I’m 100% sure I have it. Sudden onset persistent, dry cough with pre-flu symptoms? Never experienced that in my life. Would be a mighty coincidence if it’s anything else.
I’m worried for the elderly and high-risk folks in my community, but for myself this has mostly just been a surreal experience more than anything else. I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text: Hello, do you know if you have a temperature? Headache? Body aches? Fatigue? Have you called a doctor or hospital?

reply_text:
Hope it’s not COVID-19, and something else entirely. Here’s hoping, either way, that you get to feeling better soon.
I myself had every intention of going to the gym today but the more the day dragged on, the less I felt up to it. In fact, my sinuses are driving me nuts and my eyes are itchy. I’m pretty sure my allergies are starting to flare up. I’m not really self-isolating but really just staying to myself. Luckily, I can really rest because I have no work to speak of anymore. I had a large order come in yesterday and it’s already done and sent off to the client.
For now, the rest of the day is mine. Thanks to this virus, the school shut down for a week before spring break (by orders of the governor). I had to go in for a short time to get billing done, but other than that, the day is my own
Thinking it’s time to clear off my table and do some puzzles myself. I bought myself a puzzle at Christmas and I guess I can start working on it. My son and my son’s friend who lives with us both did their AMI packets for today. So now, they’re just goofing off. With a dreary day like today, I just want to rest more than I do anything else.
Get well!

reply_text:
I’m absolutely terrified of being sick with anything, so this whole thing has really just made my anxiety skyrocket. I also live with 11 people, which is more than the U.S. President has said to even gather with; what makes matters worse is the two most high risk people in my house (Dad w/ diabetes and Grandma who’s 74) are both refusing to practice social distancing and still going shopping and not washing their hands (incensed beyond belief at that).
I’ve also been doing a lot more church work since we’ve been doing online church. Pumping out social media posts, videoing children’s church lessons, and writing Bible devotions have been my days outside of the three hours I reserve for my writing orders (thankfully, business is still going strong).
I hope you feel better, @gwyneth_galvin. Does being sick affect your ability to do VO work at all?

reply_text:
misscrystal:
do you know if you have a temperature? Headache? Body aches?
Nah. I feel like you feel just before you get flu. Sorta achey, not quite right. But I’m 27, and people in my age group by and large present extremely mild symptoms or no symptoms at all.
misscrystal:
Have you called a doctor or hospital?
No, and I don’t plan to. The NHS may collapse under the weight of this crisis in the coming weeks, and I’m not going to contribute to that strain. I am perfectly happy to follow the NHS guidelines and stay home and not make contact with anyone outside of my household. I’m a rule follower

thread_text:
I’m currently the only person I know in my family or friends group that has covid-19 symptoms. UK testing is pretty much non-existent unless you’re in hospital, but I’m 100% sure I have it. Sudden onset persistent, dry cough with pre-flu symptoms? Never experienced that in my life. Would be a mighty coincidence if it’s anything else.
I’m worried for the elderly and high-risk folks in my community, but for myself this has mostly just been a surreal experience more than anything else. I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text: I heard there are two varieties of the covid-19. I was watching an elderly couple’s video on youtube of them in quarentine in Japan on a cruise ship, they can’t leave their small cabin. They both have it. The woman is ok, just with flu like symptoms but the man almost was put on a ventilator due to not being able to breath well. Somehow he is now pulling through. They are in their 60s, he has diabetis.

reply_text:
Me and my mum had been having symptoms too. Pre-flu symptoms, cough and a runny nose. And I’m kinda sure I have/had it too, since I traveled by local trains and went out to a Gig, etc. And the worst thing, in India people just don’t care enough. Only 5 in every 100k people have got tested here.
For me and my mum, well we’ve been chugging on a lot of our homemade Ayurvedic drinks, which have done their magic and the symptoms have almost vanished 80% without any external medication.
If possible, try making a hot tea using ginger, cumin, pepper, turmeric and lime.
Something similar to this => https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GNYGtaf0SYI 3

I’m worried for the elderly and high-risk folks in my community, but for myself this has mostly just been a surreal experience more than anything else. I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text:
My friend has this nutrition app that assigns you fasting periods seemingly at random. They can last from 12 to 48 hours and he swears it cured him from depending on food pretty quickly. He stopped getting grumpy if the breakfast was late, stopped obsessing about what to eat for dinner, etc., etc. Maybe we should all invest in that app.
Because I for sure started having these panicked thoughts that I should go out and buy some more rice and canned peach.

reply_text:
Ah, @gwyneth_galvin - sorry to hear this. But glad - in a kinda sardonic way - you’re getting it out of the way early.
My son has it and is self isolating - #2 daughter and I took him a care package of loo roll, washing up liquid, soap and various other bits and pieces, as well as dinner in a vacuum flask thingy tonight. We’ll probably be doing that a lot over the coming fortnight.
Here in Glasgow you cannot get paper goods for love nor money. Soap is in very short supply … but not shampoo for some reason. Shelves and shelves of shampoo and conditioner with no one interested in it. At a pinch, you can use that as shower gel and washing up liquid - it all has the same base, apparently.
Luckily, we’d put some stuff aside for Brexit, which we still have … or at least what’s left of it after Brexit didn’t really happen that much.
And yes, that EFT tapping for increasing lung capacity is a great idea. EFT for anything is a good idea. I have a tapping round for making sure your system is open to accepting everything you do for yourself, which is really useful.
@graphtersawyer - take a breath, make sure you focus on what you can control rather than the things you can’t … and, if necessary, isolate yourself in your own room as much as possible. Thinking of you.
@creativetie - take good care of yourself. Not easy to be alone and sick.
I like that we are all here for each other in this community.
Love you all!

I lived in a massive student dorm during the h1n1 outbreak and it crept down our hall one room at a time over the course of a couple weeks. I was the last person to catch it in our dorm. I’ve never been so ill in all my life. [Insert graphic details too gross for the fiverr forum]
I hope this one gives you a miss. My mum is living in Pennsylvania and has chronic severe asthma and a history of pneumonia, so I worry about her a lot. She’s on full house arrest.
Wanna do what those Italians did and play some Welsh traditional music out our flat windows???
coerdelion:
My son has it and is self isolating - #2 daughter and I took him a care package of loo roll, washing up liquid, soap and various other bits and pieces, as well as dinner in a vacuum flask thingy tonight. We’ll probably be doing that a lot over the coming fortnight.
How lucky is he to have a parent like you there! He must be so grateful to have you nearby. I miss my mum
coerdelion:
Here in Glasgow you cannot get paper goods for love nor money. Soap is in very short supply
Everything is sold out here too. I live in a less densely populated area of my county, so our local co op has been brilliant for getting stuff in and not running out immediately as the only people who go in are within walking distance of the village. We actually managed to buy a couple tins of chopped tomato AND BIN BAGS before I went into self isolation, if you can believe that

thread_name: Anybody else in self-isolation?
thread_text:
I’m currently the only person I know in my family or friends group that has covid-19 symptoms. UK testing is pretty much non-existent unless you’re in hospital, but I’m 100% sure I have it. Sudden onset persistent, dry cough with pre-flu symptoms? Never experienced that in my life. Would be a mighty coincidence if it’s anything else.
I’m worried for the elderly and high-risk folks in my community, but for myself this has mostly just been a surreal experience more than anything else. I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text:
Here are symptoms:
People may experience:
Runny nose
Sore throat
Cough
Fever
Pneumonia (which means a lung inflammation)
Difficulty breathing (severe cases)
This is the first I’ve heard of runny nose being a symptom which I’ve had for two weeks. I have never had this before. It’s just today finally getting better. I also had mild chills a few times, and swollen glands in my neck which are now ok.
This list is published by the World Health Organization
I hope it’s ok that I report some facts as I hear them here.

gwyneth_galvin:
No, and I don’t plan to. The NHS may collapse under the weight of this crisis in the coming weeks, and I’m not going to contribute to that strain. I am perfectly happy to follow the NHS guidelines and stay home and not make contact with anyone outside of my household. I’m a rule follower
Thats a very positive step from you and the right thing to do. If, god forbids, you develop a fever than you must go to the hospital.
I myself experienced some beginning flu symptoms three days ago, but I believe that it is just the season allergies that start to kick in. Today I woke up without any symptoms. I am isolating myself as well, even though I don’t have symptoms, and only going out for groceries with mask and gloves. Its the least we can do.
The main symptoms are, from what I’ve understood: dry cough, fever and difficulty to breathe. If your nose is runny, that is not corona. Its some kind of other flu.

reply_text:
With schools here shut down, it’s been nice to relax. Thankfully, the schools’ kitchens are still working and they are providing both lunch and breakfast for kids in our district. Many of them are doing it around the state of Arkansas.
And, of course, I get word that my gym has shut down so I’ll have to do home workouts. When I went to work on Monday to get checks out of the way, I grabbed my little under-the-desk bike. So, as I am sitting here at my desk, I can work my lower body. I plan on getting in a work out every day. Although I am not at high risk, I have a 76YO FIL and my husband has asthma… They are.
I’m getting ready to brave the world soon. I’m going to get some groceries. Might be a good idea to ready my menu for next week as well. No work really to do but one project (another large one). I can get it done today and then I’ll start getting the junk off my weight bench and lift weights.
Everybody stay healthy and avoid even the small crowds. I’ll brave the early morning crowds and I plan to take my kids to the school today but after that, we’re home.

I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text:
It’s nuts. I read about a Teacher who had to go back to the ER 4 times to get tested, and her and her husband, who transports elderly people, had it too. Today they mentioned looking at self swabbing kits. I think that the numbers are so unknown and this has been circulating in the US for so long now. And young people are not taking it seriously. Even though they are less likely to get sick, they can spread it. Until we have a full picture of how bad or not bad it is, we can not make rational decisions. Right now it is preparing for worse case scenarios. We have no real data from tests. We need testing. No real guidance from the Government. State leaders are figuring things out on their own. Where I live they are turning DMV (Department of Motor Vehicle) stations into testing centers. We are about 7 weeks past our first case in the US, and we are just getting testing going. Nuts.
Will everyone get tested if it is free? Non citizens? Will they risk going to the hospital and getting deported? Just my personal thoughts. Frustrating to watch it unfold in slow motion. Miss the days of the 1918 influenza pandemic when you had to wait for newspapers to print information and it took time to learn the latest news. That is a joke by the way.

All our supermarkets here are now rationing - they thought it would be like Christmas to begin with and then die down. Nope. So they’re rationing 2-4 items of each kind only. And some of them are opening up an hour early for vulnerable groups - like the over 70s - to shop first.
Of course, now they’re getting queues, where no one is observing the mandatory distance from each other, so there you are …
My son, by the way, is much better today - gaming online with his friend. Such a relief.

I’m doing fine! I’m still coughing quite a lot but apparently the cough can last weeks so no surprise there. I never developed a true fever and my self-isolation period is technically over now so I’m free to go about my business!
Oh, only joking. On the evening of my last day of isolation our PM announced a mandated lockdown Guess I’m staying at home forever! Thank god Animal Crossing just came out!

thread_name: Anybody else in self-isolation?
thread_text:
I’m currently the only person I know in my family or friends group that has covid-19 symptoms. UK testing is pretty much non-existent unless you’re in hospital, but I’m 100% sure I have it. Sudden onset persistent, dry cough with pre-flu symptoms? Never experienced that in my life. Would be a mighty coincidence if it’s anything else.
I’m worried for the elderly and high-risk folks in my community, but for myself this has mostly just been a surreal experience more than anything else. I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text:
gwyneth_galvin:
I’m doing fine!
So glad to hear it! I did worry a little when we didn’t hear from you.
gwyneth_galvin:
Thank god Animal Crossing just came out!
That seems to be keeping lots of people sane at the moment. I’ll have to check it out myself.

reply_text:
Hope everyone is doing better & staying safe…
The province I live is identified as a danger zone as there could be a major out break of the virus in the coming weeks… We are on strict curfew till further notice… Food and other essentials are either provided to areas we live for a small fee by vendors or we need to order online…
I do get a few orders on fiverr… apart from that I’ve been occupied (gardening, reading & writing some books) but it kind of feels so stressful & overwhelming sometimes…
Up to now we have only 102 cases - 3 recovered = 99 at the moment… And suspected cases to be about 229…
Please stay indoors and stay safe everyone…

I live alone (in a new foreign country) and didn’t go out for a whole 8 days today!
I felt sick in January when I first arrived here and it was really bad because I was so ill alone and I’m not used to that (I used to have other family member to help me) because I get really tired when I get sick and I had fever usually and can’t breath.
However it wasn’t COVID-19 back then but still hopefully I will not get sick again, because I don’t want that experience again
Anyhow be careful and stay safe, and I hope you are feeling good now!

reply_text:
The virus isn’ a joke. I know someone who is on a ventilator right now. He can’t climb up a flight of stairs without passing out.
As for me, I’ve been self isolating. I honestly don’t have any issues with being at home alot. I’m such a hermit nowadays, just at home doing readings (I work on 3 platforms.) I actually prefer to be alone as opposed to going out alot, except for working out. I miss that lol.
I get my groceries delivered to my house. Haven’t been to the gym sometime since mine closed. The Strip (I live in Las Vegas) is completely dark and empty. Toal ghost town.
I feel bad for some people - they can’t handle the isolation. I’ve seen people going crazy over it. Just so bad, this whole thing is unreal. I’m still happy that I am making some money.

Hope everybody is hanging in there. Last month was, strangely, my busiest fiverr month on record. I made double what I made in February.
I’m giving back by donating some of my extra income to food banks and I hired a close friend who was laid-off to do some of my editing for me. It’s not much, but it makes me feel a bit less guilty for just sitting around in my flat all day while other people stress about food and money. I can’t imagine the stress some families must be experiencing right now.
Hang in there pals xx

reply_text:
mjensen415:
A lot of us turn to video games to consume content and interact with friends.
My children and grandchildren who live in different towns, here in Montana, had done this to stay in touch with each other long before the coronavirus came alone. It works great! They play while using the chat feature to communicate.
With Roblox, even the five and 8-year-old can interact with the 17 and 18-year-old grandkids.

thread_name: Life in corona season with online jobs
thread_text:
Hi all,
Hope you all keeping well and safe at home.
Well now the impact of this deadly virus makes us to sit in home and creating crisis.Countries and cities that go through a long shutdown period will force many out of business for good, especially micro and small firms and others to lay off employees.In this situation Online jobs plays a key role to help people engaged and earn.Online job opportunities offer huge flexibility and provides quality results. Covid 19 pandemic sweeps around the world but we are better equipped to handle the situation by working through online and keeping social distancing.proudly we can say that we able to start recovery process with the effort of each and everyone.
So please all make sure that continuing the health guidance and stay safe and happy.
Thanks,
Salini sasi
